questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitation. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. ECG of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Tall, peaked T waves and a wide QRS complex on ECG in a CKD patient are classic features of hyperkalemia.

  • Hyperkalemia, defined as a serum potassium level above 0-5.5 mEq/L, is commonly associated with impaired renal excretion, especially in chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • As kidney function deteriorates, the ability to eliminate potassium declines, predisposing patients to elevated potassium levels.
  • Clinically significant hyperkalemia (usually >6.5 mEq/L) can present with muscle weakness, arrhythmias, or even cardiac arrest.
  • The most important and potentially fatal complication is its effect on cardiac conduction.
  • ECG is therefore the initial and most crucial test when hyperkalemia is suspected.
  • Typical ECG findings include:
    • Peaked T waves
    • Flattened or absent P waves
    • Prolonged PR interval
    • Widened QRS complex
  • These changes reflect increasing potassium levels and cardiac instability.
  • Causes of hyperkalemia:
  • Treatment algorithm of hyperkalemia:

Explanation of other options:

Hypokalemia (Option B): Typically causes ECG changes like U waves, flattened T waves, ST depression, and prolonged QT interval, which are not present in this case.

Hypocalcemia (Option C): Leads to QT interval prolongation due to delayed ventricular repolarization, which is not seen in this ECG.

Hypercalcemia (Option D): Characterized by a shortened QT interval from a reduced ST segment; again, not consistent with this ECG finding.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470284/

choices.text: Increase in preload causes more reduction in myocardial oxygen demand than increase in afterload
Workload is independent of myocardial oxygen consumption
Aortic stenosis results in lower pressure compared to aortic valve
Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is more significant with pressure overload than volume overload

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea and chest pain on exertion. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids. Echocardiography confirms the presence of aortic stenosis. Which of the following findings best distinguishes aortic stenosis from aortic regurgitation in terms of myocardial oxygen consumption?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Myocardial oxygen consumption increases more significantly in pressure overload (as in aortic stenosis) than in volume overload (as in aortic regurgitation).

  • Aortic stenosis (AS) leads to pressure overload on the left ventricle due to obstruction of blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve.
  • This pressure overload results in concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, which increases myocardial wall tension and oxygen demand.
  • The myocardium has to work harder to overcome the elevated pressure gradient across the valve, leading to a significant increase in myocardial oxygen consumption.
  • In contrast, aortic regurgitation (AR) primarily causes volume overload, resulting in eccentric hypertrophy.
  • Although this also increases myocardial workload, the oxygen demand rises more steeply in pressure overload than in volume overload, making this distinction important in clinical practice.
  • This explains why patients with aortic stenosis can develop angina even in the absence of coronary artery disease-due to a mismatch between the high oxygen demand of the hypertrophied myocardium and the compromised coronary blood flow.

Explanation of other options:

Increase in preload causes more reduction in myocardial oxygen demand than increase in afterload (Option A): Incorrect. Preload increases tend to augment stroke volume, but do not reduce myocardial oxygen demand. In fact, increased afterload (as in AS) raises oxygen demand more significantly.

Workload is independent of myocardial oxygen consumption (Option B): Incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly proportional to the workload of the heart, especially in terms of pressure or volume stress.

Aortic stenosis results in lower pressure compared to aortic valve (Option C): Incorrect. Aortic stenosis causes increased intraventricular pressure due to obstruction at the aortic valve, not reduced pressure.

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with fever, purpuric rash over the thigh, and migratory swelling of the right knee and left ankle joints. On cardiac auscultation, a soft diastolic murmur is noted at the apex. Laboratory tests reveal negative rheumatoid factors. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Fever, migratory polyarthritis, a diastolic murmur, and seronegativity strongly suggest acute rheumatic fever.

  • The clinical scenario presents hallmark features of acute rheumatic fever (ARF)-a febrile illness following group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis, with major manifestations including migratory arthritis, carditis, and skin findings.
  • The Jones Criteria guide the diagnosis, and this patient demonstrates:
    • Migratory arthritis involving large joints (right knee and left ankle)
    • Carditis, as evidenced by the diastolic apical murmur, likely a Carey Coombs murmur due to early mitral valvulitis
    • A history of fever
    • Seronegativity for rheumatoid factor, ruling out autoimmune arthritides
  • ARF typically manifests 2-3 weeks post-streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • The polyarthritis is often migratory and transient.
  • Carditis may involve the mitral and/or aortic valves, initially causing regurgitation, with a risk of progression to chronic rheumatic heart disease.
  • The Carey Coombs murmur, a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex, is specific to ARF and reflects inflammatory thickening of the mitral valve leaflets, not stenosis or regurgitation per se.
  • Other late features include chorea, subcutaneous nodules, and erythema marginatum, though they are less common.

Explanation of other options:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Option B): Typically presents with chronic joint swelling and stiffness, especially in the morning. Systemic JIA may cause fever, but diastolic murmur and migratory arthritis are not characteristic.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): A chronic autoimmune condition affecting adults with symmetric polyarthritis and usually positive rheumatoid factor. The acute presentation and seronegativity make this diagnosis unlikely.

Seronegative arthropathy (Option D): Encompasses conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, and psoriatic arthritis, which usually involve axial skeleton or entheses, often chronic and without a diastolic murmur or acute febrile course.

choices.text: Change to salbutamol MDI twice daily

questions.text:
A 26-year-old patient with a history of bronchial asthma experiences two daytime episodes and one night time episode per week. He uses albuterol as needed. Post-bronchodilator spirometry shows an improvement in FEV1 from 76% to 83%.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The patient has mild persistent asthma and requires initiation of an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) like fluticasone for long-term control.

  • This patient's symptoms; daytime attacks more than once weekly and nighttime symptoms, fulfill the criteria for mild persistent asthma.
  • The partial reversibility of airway obstruction seen on spirometry (FEV1 improving from 76% to 83% after a bronchodilator) also supports this diagnosis.
  • In such cases, relying solely on short-acting β2-agonists like albuterol is not sufficient.
  • Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) such as fluticasone are the cornerstone of controller therapy, reducing airway inflammation and the frequency of exacerbations.
  • According to the stepwise approach to asthma management:
    • Step 1 (intermittent): PRN short-acting β2-agonists (SABAs) for symptoms less than once a week.
    • Step 2 (mild persistent): Regular low-dose ICS is introduced, typically when symptoms occur ≥3 times per week or nocturnal symptoms occur ≥1 per week.
    • Step 3-5: Progressive escalation depending on control, including higher ICS doses, LABAs, oral steroids, and biologics like omalizumab or mepolizumab.

Explanation of other options:

Add oral prednisolone 10 mg daily (Option A): Oral corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or acute exacerbations; their chronic use is avoided due to systemic side effects.

Continue albuterol whenever required (Option B): While effective for symptom relief, albuterol alone does not address the underlying inflammation seen in persistent asthma.

Change to salbutamol MDI twice daily (Option D): Salbutamol is not intended for regular scheduled use. Maintenance therapy in persistent asthma requires an ICS, not increased use of a SABA.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with partially compensated respiratory alkalosis with a high anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after ingesting a large quantity of salicylic acid tablets. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals:
pH = 7.30
pCO2 = 16 mmHg
HCO2- = 6.3 mmol/L
Na+ = 135 mmol/L
K+ = 4.5 mmol/L
Cl- = 113.7 mmol/L
Lactate = Normal

Which of the following best describes the acid-base abnormality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The patient's ABG shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with evidence of partial respiratory alkalosis, commonly seen in salicylate poisoning.

  • This question revolves around interpreting an ABG in the context of salicylate poisoning, which characteristically causes a mixed acid-base disorder.
  • Here's a stepwise interpretation:
    • Step 1: Check pH
      • pH = 7.30 → Indicates acidemia
    • Step 2: Identify the primary disorder
      • HCO3- = 6.3 mmol/L (Low) → Suggests primary metabolic acidosis
      • pCO2 = 16 mmHg (Low) → Normally, this would compensate for metabolic acidosis, but the level is lower than expected, hinting at a respiratory alkalosis component as well.
    • Step 3: Calculate the anion gap
      • Anion gap = Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-)
      • = 135 - (113.7 + 6.3) = 15 mEq/L
      • Normal AG = 6-12 mEq/L → Thus, elevated anion gap
    • Step 4: Assess respiratory compensation using Winter's formula
      • Expected pCO2 = (1.5 × HCO3-) + 8 ± 2 = (1.5 × 6.3) + 8 = 17.45 ± 2 → Range: 15.5-19.5 mmHg
  • Actual pCO2 = 16 mmHg → Within range → Compensatory respiratory alkalosis
  • However, in salicylate poisoning, respiratory alkalosis may precede metabolic acidosis, creating a true mixed disorder.
  • So, the acid-base status is:
    • Primary high anion gap metabolic acidosis
    • With superimposed respiratory alkalosis → mixed picture
  • This pattern is characteristic of salicylate (aspirin) toxicity due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center and resulting hyperventilation.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis (Option B): Incorrect. The pCO2 is low, not high, and HCO3- is also low, ruling out both respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis.

Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis (Option C): Incorrect. The respiratory system has partially compensated for the metabolic acidosis, as pCO2 is within the Winter's predicted range.

Respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect. This pattern would show high pCO2 and high HCO3-, opposite to the findings here.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of easy fatiguability, anemia, hyperpigmentation over the knuckles, oral mucosa, palms, and hands, along with tachycardia. Blood pressure is recorded at 80/60 mmHg, and serum sodium is 130 mEq/L. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The constellation of fatigue, anemia, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and hyponatremia is typical of Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency).

  • Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison's disease, results from destruction or dysfunction of the adrenal cortex, leading to decreased production of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens.
  • The most common causes include autoimmune adrenalitis (most common worldwide), tuberculosis (most common in India), fungal infections, HIV/AIDS, metastatic malignancies, or bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • The clinical features stem from hormone deficiencies:
    • Glucocorticoid deficiency causes: fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, and hyponatremia (dilutional).
    • Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
    • Excess ACTH (due to lack of cortisol feedback) results in hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas, skin creases, and mucosa.
    • Androgen deficiency in females may cause reduced body hair and libido.
  • Investigations:
    • Random cortisol: >500 nmol/L rules out adrenal insufficiency.
    • Short ACTH stimulation test: If cortisol remains <500 nmol/L after stimulation, it confirms adrenal insufficiency.
    • Plasma renin and aldosterone levels help detect mineralocorticoid deficiency.
    • Autoimmune adrenal antibodies may be checked if autoimmune cause is suspected; CT/MRI may be used in antibody-negative cases.
  • Treatment:
    • Glucocorticoid replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is first-line; prednisolone or dexamethasone are alternatives.
    • Mineralocorticoid replacement: Fludrocortisone corrects aldosterone deficiency.

Explanation of other options:

Conn's syndrome (Option A): Characterized by hyperaldosteronism, leading to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Hyperpigmentation and hypotension are not features.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option C): May present with fatigue and anemia, but does not explain hyperpigmentation, hypotension, or hyponatremia. Neurological symptoms like paresthesias and gait disturbances would typically be present.

Cushing syndrome (Option D): Features include central obesity, moon face, purple striae, and hypertension due to cortisol excess. Hypotension and hyperpigmentation are generally not observed, making it unlikely here.

questions.text: A patient presents with weakness of the right upper and lower limbs, along with left-sided facial nerve palsy and horizontal gaze palsy to the left side. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Foville syndrome results from a pontine lesion affecting the abducens nucleus, facial nerve, and corticospinal tract, producing ipsilateral facial and gaze palsy with contralateral hemiparesis.

  • The clinical presentation of right-sided hemiparesis (upper and lower limbs), along with left-sided cranial nerve VII palsy and horizontal gaze palsy to the left, is characteristic of Foville syndrome.
  • This syndrome arises from a lesion in the dorsal pons, typically involving the abducens nucleus (CN VI), facial nerve fascicles (CN VII), paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), and corticospinal tract.
  • Key findings in Foville syndrome include:
    • Ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy (due to abducens nucleus or PPRF involvement)
    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial palsy
    • Contralateral hemiparesis from corticospinal tract involvement
  • These findings distinguish Foville from other pontine syndromes that may share overlapping features but lack conjugate gaze deficits.

Brainstem stroke syndromes

  • Foville Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis + Conjugate gaze paralysis towards the side of brainstem lesion
  • Weber Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN III palsy (ptosis, pupillary dilation) + contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract).
  • Millard-Gubler Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis (No gaze paralysis - differentiates it from Foville syndrome) (Option A ruled out)
  • Benedikt Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN III palsy + contralateral ataxia and tremor (red nucleus involvement). (Option B ruled out)
  • Wallenberg Syndrome: Ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ataxia, dysphagia, and hoarseness + contralateral loss of pain/temperature.
  • Locked-In Syndrome: Quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. (Option D ruled out)
  • Raymond Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + contralateral hemiparesis.
  • Dejerine Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN XII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis and impaired proprioception/vibration.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560896/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544268/#

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent fatigue, bleeding from the gums, and hair changes. On examination, he has pallor, diffuse hair loss, and noticeable depigmentation of scalp hair. Which of the following trace element deficiencies best explains his clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Zinc deficiency leads to anemia, alopecia, depigmented hair, and bleeding gums-findings all present in this patient.

  • Zinc is a vital trace element that serves as a cofactor in over 300 enzymatic reactions, playing crucial roles in immune function, protein and nucleic acid synthesis, wound healing, and cell division.
  • It is also essential for maintaining healthy skin, mucosa, and hair pigmentation.
  • In this patient, the combination of:
    • Anemia
    • Bleeding gums
    • Diffuse alopecia
    • Depigmented hair
    • Strongly suggests a zinc deficiency.
  • These findings result from impaired cellular functions due to inadequate activity of zinc-dependent enzymes.
  • Clinical Features of Zinc Deficiency:
    • Dermatologic: Dry, scaly skin, poor wound healing, alopecia, hair depigmentation
    • Hematologic: Anemia (due to poor iron utilization)
    • Oral: Bleeding gums, glossitis
    • Immune: Increased susceptibility to infections
    • Neurologic/Psychiatric: Mood changes, irritability
    • Growth & Development: Hypogonadism, growth retardation in children
  • It is commonly seen in individuals with:
    • Poor nutritional intake (especially low animal protein diets)
    • Malabsorption syndromes
    • Chronic liver disease
    • Alcoholism
    • Increased zinc losses through diarrhea

Explanation of other options:

Copper (Option A): Copper deficiency can cause microcytic anemia and neutropenia, and sometimes peripheral neuropathy, but hair depigmentation and bleeding gums are more characteristic of zinc deficiency.

Iron (Option B): Iron deficiency anemia presents with fatigue, pallor, and spoon nails, but does not typically cause bleeding gums, alopecia, or hair depigmentation, which are more specific to zinc deficiency.

Fluoride (Option C): Fluoride is mainly involved in dental and skeletal health. Deficiency increases the risk of dental caries, but does not produce systemic symptoms such as anemia or hair changes.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4082809/

choices.text: GH levels <0.4 µg/L after 1 hour of 75 g oral glucose load
Single early morning fasting GH level to establish the diagnosis
Age-specific IGF-1 levels are useful for screening
GH levels are used to assess disease severity

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with persistent headaches and progressive visual disturbance. On examination, he has prominent frontal bossing, thickened palms and soles, spaced central incisors, and coarse facial features. He is hypertensive and diabetic. What is the most appropriate screening test to evaluate his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Serum IGF-1, which reflects integrated GH secretion, is the most sensitive and reliable screening test for acromegaly.

  • The patient's features-frontal bossing, acral enlargement, coarse facies, visual symptoms, and associated hypertension and diabetes-are classical signs of acromegaly, a disorder resulting from chronic growth hormone (GH) excess, usually due to a GH-secreting pituitary macroadenoma.
  • The first-line screening test is serum Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1), measured against age-specific reference ranges.
  • IGF-1 is more stable and reflects long-term GH exposure, unlike GH which has pulsatile secretion and fluctuating levels throughout the day.

Acromegaly - Summary and Clinical Essentials

  • Acromegaly is primarily due to excess growth hormone (GH) secretion, most commonly from a pituitary somatotroph macroadenoma (>1 cm).
  • Cause:
    • Mixed mammosomatotroph tumors (secreting GH and PRL)
    • Acidophilic stem cell adenomas (PRL co-secretion → hypogonadism, galactorrhea)
    • Ectopic GH/GHRH secretion from carcinoid tumors, pancreas, lungs, or ovaries
  • Clinical Features
    • Acral Changes:
      • Frontal bossing, enlarged hands and feet
      • Mandibular overgrowth (prognathism), interdental spacing
    • Soft Tissue Features:
      • Coarse facial features, macroglossia
      • Increased heel pad (>25 mm), larger ring/shoe/glove size
    • Visceromegaly:
      • Cardiomegaly, thyroid enlargement
    • Other Signs:
      • Hyperhidrosis, oily skin, deep voice
      • Arthropathy, kyphosis, carpal tunnel syndrome
      • Acanthosis nigricans, skin tags, muscle weakness
  • Complications
    • Metabolic: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension
    • Cardiac/Respiratory: Cardiomyopathy, sleep apnea
    • Neoplastic: Colon polyps and malignancy
    • Mass effect: Visual disturbances, hypopituitarism
  • Investigations
    • Screening test: Age-adjusted serum IGF-1 levels (stable marker of GH excess)
    • Diagnostic test: 75 g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT)
      • GH suppression to <0.4 µg/L confirms diagnosis
      • 20% may show paradoxical GH rise
    • GH levels: Not reliable for diagnosis or severity due to pulsatile secretion
    • MRI Brain with contrast: Investigation of choice for tumor localization
    • Other labs: Elevated PRL (25% cases), assess other pituitary hormones
  • Management
    • First-line: Transsphenoidal surgery (especially for GH-secreting adenomas)
    • Medical therapy:
      • Somatostatin receptor ligands (SRLs): Octreotide, Lanreotide
      • GH receptor antagonist: Pegvisomant (normalizes IGF-1 in ~70%)
      • Dopamine agonists: High-dose cabergoline (modest effect)
    • Radiotherapy: For non-responders or surgical failures

Explanation of other options:

GH levels <0.4 µg/L after 1 hour of 75 g oral glucose load (Option A): This is a confirmatory test, not a screening test. It is used after IGF-1 is found to be elevated.

Single early morning fasting GH level to establish the diagnosis (Option B): Incorrect. GH secretion is pulsatile and highly variable, making a single random or fasting level unreliable for diagnosis.

GH levels are used to assess disease severity (Option D): Incorrect. GH levels may correlate poorly with clinical severity due to fluctuations. IGF-1 is more reliable for both screening and monitoring.

Reference:

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1155/2024/5085905

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of recurrent lung infections. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Recurrent respiratory infections along with dextrocardia on chest X-ray are hallmark features of Kartagener syndrome.

  • Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired ciliary structure and function.
  • This ciliary dysfunction leads to poor mucociliary clearance, resulting in chronic respiratory tract infections.
  • Kartagener syndrome is classically defined by the triad of:
    • Situs inversus (including dextrocardia)
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Chronic sinusitis
  • It affects approximately 50% of patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia.
  • The underlying defect in ciliary motility contributes to:
    • Impaired clearance of respiratory secretions → recurrent lung infections and bronchiectasis
    • Impaired mucociliary action in the sinuses → chronic sinusitis
    • Abnormal embryonic organ rotation → situs inversus
    • Sperm motility issues → male infertility
  • Diagnostic criteria include:
    • Clinical history of chronic respiratory symptoms from early life
    • Presence of situs inversus or sibling with it
    • Evidence of reduced or absent mucociliary clearance
    • Electron microscopy showing ultrastructural ciliary abnormalities
  • Management is supportive, focusing on treating infections, physiotherapy, and in severe cases, lung transplantation.

Explanation of other options:

Cystic fibrosis (Option B): Though it causes recurrent chest infections and bronchiectasis, it does not feature dextrocardia or situs inversus. Sweat chloride testing and genetic analysis confirm diagnosis.

DiGeorge syndrome (Option C): Presents with cardiac defects, thymic hypoplasia, and hypocalcemia, not chronic lung infections or situs inversus.

Down syndrome (Option D): Can have respiratory issues due to structural anomalies, but does not present with dextrocardia or the classic triad seen in Kartagener syndrome.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3519024/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/kartagener-syndrome

questions.text: A patient presents with headache and confusion and is diagnosed with a brain tumor. Family history reveals the presence of both brain and kidney tumors in close relatives. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The combination of brain tumors, kidney tumors, and a positive family history strongly suggests Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome.

  • VHL syndrome is a rare, inherited autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene, predisposing affected individuals to a variety of benign and malignant tumors across multiple organ systems.
  • This includes brain and kidney tumors, which are central to the case described.
  • Common manifestations include:
    • CNS hemangioblastomas: especially in the cerebellum, leading to headache, ataxia, and vomiting.
    • Retinal hemangioblastomas: which may impair vision and may be an early sign.
    • Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type): Occurs in ~70% of patients and is a leading cause of mortality in VHL.
    • Pheochromocytomas: Can cause hypertension, palpitations, and sweating.
    • Pancreatic cysts and neuroendocrine tumors
    • Endolymphatic sac tumors: May lead to hearing loss.
  • Diagnostic criteria (Dutch and Danish):
    • With a family history: One VHL-associated tumor and a first-degree relative with VHL.
    • Without family history: At least two distinct VHL-related manifestations (e.g., cerebellar hemangioblastoma and renal cell carcinoma). Genetic testing confirming a pathogenic variant in the VHL gene is definitive.
  • Management is multidisciplinary:
    • Surgical removal of CNS hemangioblastomas, retinal tumors, pheochromocytomas, and renal tumors.
    • Targeted therapies such as Pazopanib for advanced renal cancers and Belzutifan for VHL-associated tumors.
    • Kidney transplant may be needed after bilateral nephrectomy in cases with extensive renal involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Neurofibromatosis (Option A): NF1 and NF2 can involve brain tumors (optic gliomas or vestibular schwannomas), but kidney tumors are not typical features.

Li-Fraumeni syndrome (Option B): Associated with brain tumors, breast cancer, sarcomas, and adrenocortical carcinomas, but not classically with kidney tumors.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Option D): A vasculitic disorder with asthma and eosinophilia; tumors are not part of its clinical spectrum, ruling it out in this context.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1463/#

https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/def/von-hippel-lindau-syndrome

choices.text: Rheumatic heart disease with mitral stenosis
Bicuspid aortic valve with Aortic regurgitation

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and pedal edema. Jugular venous pressure (JVP) shows a rapid Y descent. Auscultation reveals a high-pitched early diastolic sound. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The presence of rapid Y descent on JVP along with a high-pitched diastolic sound suggests chronic constrictive pericarditis.

  • Chronic constrictive pericarditis results from pericardial thickening, fibrosis, and sometimes calcification, which restricts diastolic filling of the heart.
  • Over time, this condition impairs ventricular filling and elevates systemic venous pressures, causing signs of right heart failure such as pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites.
  • Key features include:
    • Elevated JVP with rapid Y descent: Due to abrupt early diastolic filling before sudden pericardial restriction halts further expansion.
    • High-pitched diastolic sound ("pericardial knock"): Heard early in diastole, representing sudden cessation of ventricular filling due to the stiff pericardium.
    • Kussmaul's sign: Rise in JVP on inspiration.
    • Fatigue, ascites, peripheral edema: Reflect systemic venous congestion.
    • Atrial fibrillation: Common due to chronic atrial dilation and hypertrophy.
  • Investigations:
    • Chest X-ray and CT scan: May reveal pericardial calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Shows thickened pericardium and characteristic Doppler flow patterns.
    • Cardiac catheterization: Confirms equalization of diastolic pressures, helping differentiate from restrictive cardiomyopathy.
  • Management:
    • Medical therapy: Diuretics to manage symptoms.
    • Definitive treatment: Pericardiectomy, which removes the thickened pericardium. Though curative in many, it carries a significant operative risk and variable outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): Presents with prominent X descent and absent Y descent on JVP, due to restriction of diastolic filling. The presence of rapid Y descent in this case argues against tamponade.

RHD with mitral stenosis (Option C): Typically presents with a loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic rumble, not a high-pitched knock or rapid Y descent.

Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation (Option D): Produces a high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border, but does not explain the rapid Y descent or right-sided signs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with palpitations and light headedness. On examination, her pulse is irregularly irregular with a heart rate of 150 beats per minute. Auscultation reveals a loud P2 but no murmurs. What is the most likely finding on her jugular venous pulse (JVP) examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

In atrial fibrillation, ineffective atrial contractions lead to absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse.

  • This patient's irregularly irregular rhythm and high heart rate (150 bpm) are classic for atrial fibrillation (AF), the most common sustained arrhythmia.
  • AF is characterized by disorganized atrial electrical activity, resulting in the absence of coordinated atrial contraction.
  • Since the right atrium does not contract effectively, the 'a' wave which represents right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve is absent in the JVP waveform.
  • Additional Features of Atrial Fibrillation:
    • Mechanism: Multiple re-entrant circuits and ectopic atrial activity override SA node pacing
    • Pulse: Irregularly irregular, varying pulse volume
    • ECG Findings:
      • Absent P waves
      • Irregularly irregular R-R intervals
      • Fibrillatory baseline waves (especially in lead V1)
    • Heart Rate: Often rapid initially (120-160 bpm), slows down with rate control
    • Heart Sounds: May have variable S1 intensity, but no murmurs unless structural heart disease is present
    • Auscultation finding in this patient: Loud P2 may suggest pulmonary hypertension as a consequence of AF or underlying mitral valve disease

JVP Waveforms:

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9271481/

questions.text: In a patient with type 1 diabetes with 3rd stage of beta cell damage, which of the following situations is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Stage 2 of type 1 diabetes is defined by the presence of islet autoimmunity along with dysglycemia but without overt symptoms.

  • Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disease characterized by T-cell-mediated destruction of pancreatic β-cells, leading to absolute insulin deficiency.
  • It progresses through three defined stages before becoming symptomatic.

Stages of T1DM Development:

  • Stage 1:
    • Positive for ≥2 islet autoantibodies (e.g., GAD65, IA-2, ZnT8, ICA)
    • Normoglycemia on glucose testing (Option A ruled out)
    • Clinically asymptomatic
  • Stage 2:
    • Positive islet autoantibodies (same as stage 1)
    • Dysglycemia (abnormal glucose tolerance, elevated fasting glucose or postprandial glucose)
    • Still asymptomatic
  • Stage 3:
    • Islet autoantibody positive
    • Hyperglycemia exceeding diagnostic threshold for diabetes
    • Clinically symptomatic (e.g., polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, possible DKA)
  • The patient is autoantibody positive and has dysglycemia but no overt symptoms yet, making this Stage 2 of T1DM.
  • This staging allows for early identification of individuals at risk for T1DM, which is especially important for clinical trials and preventive strategies.

Explanation of other options:

Autoimmune negative with normoglycemia (Option C): This individual does not have autoimmune T1DM and shows no biochemical evidence of dysglycemia-unlikely to progress.

Autoimmune negative with dysglycemia (Option D): May suggest Type 2 diabetes or another form of non-autoimmune dysglycemia, not T1DM.

choices.text: Severe disease can cause vision loss
NO SPECS criteria is used for this condition
10% of isolated cases are present without hyperthyroidism
Condition will improve simultaneously with improvement in thyrotoxic state

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with complaints of neck swelling. She reports weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Grave's ophthalmopathy does not necessarily improve in parallel with control of hyperthyroidism and often requires separate treatment.

  • The patient presents with classic features of Grave's disease, an autoimmune thyroid disorder characterized by diffuse toxic goiter, thyrotoxicosis, and Grave's orbitopathy (thyroid eye disease).
  • Though treating hyperthyroidism helps reduce the autoimmune trigger, Grave's ophthalmopathy follows an independent course and may worsen or persist despite achieving a euthyroid state.

Key Points about Grave's Disease:

  • Etiology: Autoimmune disorder with TSH receptor-stimulating antibodies (TRAb)
  • Epidemiology: Common in women aged 20-50
  • Thyroid findings: Diffuse, enlarged gland ± bruit
  • Thyrotoxic symptoms: Weight loss, palpitations, heat intolerance, tremors
  • Ophthalmopathy (thyroid eye disease):
    • Exophthalmos, lid lag, periorbital edema, conjunctival injection
    • Severe cases may lead to optic nerve compression and vision loss

Thyroid Eye Disease (TED):

  • Occurs due to inflammatory cell infiltration, leading to extraocular muscle swelling and orbital fat expansion
  • Can occur with or without overt hyperthyroidism
  • ~10% of patients have eye involvement while being euthyroid or hypothyroid
  • Eye symptoms can worsen after radioiodine therapy and do not always resolve with thyroid function normalization

Explanation of other options:

Severe disease can cause vision loss (Option A): True. Orbital apex compression can cause optic neuropathy and visual field loss.

NO SPECS criteria is used for this condition (Option B): True. This is the grading system for Grave's orbitopathy severity:

0: No signs/symptoms

1: Lid lag/retraction

2: Soft tissue involvement

3: Proptosis

4: Extraocular muscle involvement

5: Corneal involvement

6: Sight loss

10% of isolated cases are present without hyperthyroidism (Option C): True. Eye involvement can occur in euthyroid or hypothyroid states (~10% of cases).

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of weight loss, palpitations, heat intolerance, and hand tremors. On examination, she has exophthalmos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The combination of weight loss, tachycardia, tremors, heat intolerance, and exophthalmos is characteristic of Grave's disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

  • Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder in which thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs) activate the TSH receptor, leading to thyroid hormone overproduction.
  • It is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, especially in young and middle-aged women.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Constitutional: Weight loss despite normal or increased appetite, fatigue
    • Cardiovascular: Palpitations, tachycardia, atrial fibrillation
    • Neurological: Tremors, anxiety, hyperreflexia
    • Thermoregulatory: Heat intolerance, excessive sweating
    • Ophthalmic: Exophthalmos (proptosis), lid lag, diplopia due to Grave's orbitopathy
    • Dermatological: Warm, moist skin; pretibial myxedema (rare)
    • GI and MSK: Increased stool frequency; osteopenia and muscle weakness
  • Investigations:
    • Thyroid Profile:
      • ↓ TSH, ↑ T3/T4 levels
      • T3 toxicosis (↑ T3, normal T4) may occur
    • Autoantibodies:
      • TSI (TRAb): Specific for Grave's
      • Anti-TPO may also be present
    • Thyroid Scan:
      • Diffusely increased uptake with 99mTc or 123I
    • Doppler Ultrasound:
      • Increased vascularity of thyroid gland
    • Management:
      • Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil or Methimazole
      • Radioiodine therapy: Preferred in adults not opting for surgery
      • Surgery (thyroidectomy): For large goiters, pregnancy, or drug failure
      • Steroids and supportive care for ophthalmopathy if present

Explanation of other options:

Addison's disease (Option A): Presents with fatigue, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and electrolyte abnormalities like hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. Exophthalmos and heat intolerance are not seen.

Parkinson's disease (Option B): Primarily a movement disorder with resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. It does not cause systemic features like weight loss or hypermetabolism.

Alzheimer's disease (Option D): A neurodegenerative condition causing progressive cognitive decline and memory loss, not associated with systemic symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A young athlete presented with chest pain and dyspnea. His brother passed away due to sudden cardiac death. He is diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). A harsh systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. Which of the following maneuvers will increase the intensity of this murmur?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload, exacerbating left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) in HCM and thereby increasing the murmur.

  • This is a classic case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM), an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO), and increased risk of sudden cardiac death, especially in young athletes.
  • Genetic mutations:
    • β-myosin heavy chain: Associated with significant hypertrophy and earlier presentation.
    • Troponin T: May cause minimal hypertrophy but high risk of sudden cardiac death due to myocardial disarray.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • The thickened septum narrows the LVOT.
    • Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve further blocks the outflow.
    • LV becomes non-compliant, impairing diastolic filling.
    • Myocyte disarray increases risk of arrhythmias, especially ventricular fibrillation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Exertional angina, dyspnea, and syncope due to dynamic obstruction and poor diastolic filling.
    • Sudden cardiac death often during exertion, especially in genetically predisposed athletes.
    • Jerky or bifid pulse due to dynamic changes in LV ejection.
    • Harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border, which mimics aortic stenosis but lacks radiation to the neck.
  • Why murmur increases with Valsalva:
    • The Valsalva maneuver reduces venous return and preload, leading to a smaller LV cavity. This enhances septal-mitral valve contact, worsening the dynamic LVOT obstruction and increasing the intensity of the murmur in HOCM.

Auscultatory changes with maneuvers:

Explanation of other options:

Squatting (Option A): Increases both venous return and afterload, which distends the LV cavity and relieves the obstruction, thereby reducing murmur intensity.

Leaning forward with head down/up (Option B): This maneuver accentuates diastolic murmurs, particularly of aortic regurgitation, but has no significant impact on HOCM murmur.

Hand grip (Option C): Increases afterload, which reduces the gradient across the obstructed LVOT and diminishes murmur intensity in HCM.

Reference:

https://litfl.com/hypertrophic-cardiomyopathy-hcm-ecg-library/

https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article-abstract/37/5/498/2466086?redirectedFrom=fulltext

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1168371/

https://www.healio.com/cardiology/learn-the-heart/cardiology-review/topic-reviews/s2-heart-sound#

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will cause Torsades de Pointes if given with erythromycin?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Astemizole significantly prolongs the QT interval, and when co-administered with erythromycin (a CYP3A4 inhibitor), it increases the risk of life-threatening Torsades de Pointes.

  • Torsades de Pointes (TdP) is a distinctive form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that occurs in the setting of prolonged QT interval, often drug-induced.
  • It can deteriorate into ventricular fibrillation and cause sudden cardiac death.
  • Risk factors include electrolyte imbalance (especially hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), bradycardia, congenital long QT syndromes, and most importantly drugs that prolong the QT interval.

Astemizole

  • Astemizole is a non-sedating H1 antihistamine, previously used for allergic rhinitis and urticaria.
  • It has now been withdrawn in many countries due to its high risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
  • Mechanism:
    • Astemizole and its active metabolite desmethylastemizole inhibit the (Ikr/hERG) potassium channel, which is critical for ventricular repolarization.
    • This blockade prolongs the QT interval on ECG, predisposing to early after depolarizations (EADs) and triggering Torsades de Pointes.
    • When combined with erythromycin, a known CYP3A4 inhibitor, metabolism of astemizole is inhibited, leading to elevated plasma levels and exacerbated QT prolongation.
    • This interaction is synergistically proarrhythmic and potentially fatal.

Explanation of other options:

Levofloxacin (Option B): A fluoroquinolone that can prolong the QT interval on its own. However, it is less likely to interact significantly with erythromycin as it is not extensively metabolized by CYP3A4, and the risk of Torsades is lower than with astemizole.

Amoxicillin (Option C): A beta-lactam antibiotic with no known effect on cardiac repolarization or QT interval. It does not interact with erythromycin in a way that would cause QT prolongation or TdP.

Ceftriaxone (Option D): A third-generation cephalosporin that is cardiac-neutral. It neither affects QT interval nor interacts with CYP enzymes in a way that predisposes to TdP.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9165570/#

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8023479/#

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/astemizole

choices.text: Check pulse and give synchronized DCP
Give synchronized DC and continue chest compression

questions.text: What is the next best step in management of a pulseless patient with the following rhythm?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

In a pulseless patient with suspected ventricular tachycardia (VT), the immediate step is unsynchronized defibrillation with continued chest compressions.

  • The clinical situation describes a pulseless patient with a wide complex regular rhythm, strongly suggesting pulseless monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT).
  • In this scenario, defibrillation is the cornerstone of management.

Understanding Ventricular Tachycardia (VT):

  • VT is a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia that arises from the ventricles.
  • Defined as ≥3 consecutive wide QRS complexes at a rate >100 bpm.
  • Monomorphic VT: All QRS complexes appear similar; usually due to a reentrant circuit in scarred myocardium.
  • Polymorphic VT: Varying QRS morphology; often associated with prolonged QT or electrolyte abnormalities.
  • ECG Findings in Monomorphic VT:
    • Wide QRS complexes (>120 ms)
    • Regular rhythm
    • Absence of clear P waves
    • May mimic bundle branch block patterns
  • Management Approach Based on Hemodynamic Status:
    • Stable VT (with pulse):
      • Antiarrhythmic drugs like amiodarone, procainamide, or lidocaine
    • Unstable VT (with pulse):
      • Synchronized cardioversion
    • Pulseless VT or VF (ventricular fibrillation):
      • Immediate unsynchronized defibrillation (not synchronized cardioversion)
      • High-quality CPR must be continued without delay
    • Why Defibrillation + CPR is Critical:
      • Defibrillation delivers a shock at a random phase of the cardiac cycle (unsynchronized), aiming to stop the chaotic electrical activity and allow the heart to reestablish a perfusing rhythm.
      • CPR maintains circulation until return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) is achieved.

Explanation of other options:

Defibrillate and check pulse (Option B): Pulse check should be done after delivering the shock and resuming CPR for 2 minutes, not before.

Check pulse and give synchronized DC (Option C): Synchronized DC cardioversion is indicated for hemodynamically unstable VT with pulse-not in a pulseless patient.

Give synchronized DC and continue chest compression (Option D): Synchronized shocks are not appropriate for pulseless rhythms; defibrillation (unsynchronized) is required.

choices.text: IV thiamine followed by dextrose infusion
Injection vitamin K followed by dextrose infusion

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented to the emergency in an unconscious state. Relatives stated that he had a similar episode of binge drinking one week back. On examination, his glucose was 49 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

In an unconscious alcoholic with hypoglycemia, IV thiamine must be given before glucose to prevent precipitation or worsening of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Wernicke Encephalopathy: "The Emergency Neurological Manifestation of Thiamine Deficiency"

  • This case is a classic presentation of Wernicke encephalopathy due to chronic alcohol use and malnutrition, worsened by hypoglycemia.
  • Key Triad of Wernicke Encephalopathy:
    • Confusion
    • Ataxia
    • Ophthalmoplegia (or nystagmus)
  • Though all three may not be present initially, altered mental status in an alcoholic with hypoglycemia is Wernicke encephalopathy until proven otherwise.
  • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a cofactor in glucose metabolism, particularly for the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.
  • In thiamine deficiency, giving glucose without prior thiamine results in accumulation of lactate and pyruvate, worsening neuronal energy failure → leading to irreversible neurological damage or coma.
  • Treatment Protocol:
    • IV Thiamine: 100-500 mg IV over 30 min (depending on severity)
    • Then: Give IV dextrose (e.g., 25% or 50%)
    • Follow with maintenance fluids and supportive care
    • Note: IM or oral thiamine may be used later but IV is essential in emergency settings for rapid CNS availability.
  • MRI Findings (if done):
    • Symmetric hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR in:
      • Mammillary bodies
      • Medial thalami
      • Periaqueductal gray matter
      • Tectal plate
      • Around the 3rd and 4th ventricles

Explanation of other options:

Injection vitamin K followed by dextrose infusion (Option B): Vitamin K is used for coagulopathy in liver disease or anticoagulant overdose; it has no role in reversing altered sensorium due to thiamine deficiency.

IV 25% dextrose (Option C): Administering dextrose before thiamine in a thiamine-deficient patient can precipitate acute Wernicke encephalopathy, making this dangerous without thiamine priming.

NS infusion (Option D): While normal saline may help with volume resuscitation, it does not correct hypoglycemia or treat underlying vitamin B1 deficiency, hence is inadequate in this scenario.

Reference:

Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome | National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (nih.gov)

Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome: Practice Essentials, Background, Etiology (medscape.com)

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482360/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470344/

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with complaints of chest pain and dyspnea. Pleural fluid analysis reveals a pleural fluid protein to serum protein ratio >0.5 and a pleural fluid LDH to serum LDH ratio >0.4. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The pleural fluid profile is consistent with exudative pleural effusion, and among the options given, tuberculosis is the most likely cause.

  • The provided pleural fluid analysis shows a pleural protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5 and a pleural LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.4, which are indicative of exudative pleural effusion, as per Light's criteria.

Light's Criteria for Exudative Effusion:

  • Pleural fluid is considered exudative if any one of the following is true:
    • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
    • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
    • Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 the upper limit of normal serum LDH
  • The presence of an exudative effusion narrows down the differential diagnosis to conditions causing pleural inflammation, such as:
    • Tuberculosis
    • Malignancy
    • Pneumonia (parapneumonic effusion)
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., RA, SLE)

Tuberculous Pleuritis:

  • A common cause of exudative pleural effusion, especially in endemic regions.
  • Typically presented with lymphocyte-predominant fluid, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA >40 IU/L), and interferon gamma (>140 pg/mL).
  • May also have low glucose and high protein levels.

Causes of Pleural Effusion

Reference:

://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4753987/#sec4

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448189/#

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8578877/#

questions.text: What is the expected finding in a patient with the following CXR?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Flail chest causes paradoxical breathing due to a free-floating chest wall segment that moves opposite to normal during respiration.

  • Flail chest is a traumatic condition resulting from fractures of three or more consecutive ribs in at least two places, creating a flail segment that becomes mechanically independent from the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This segment moves inward during inspiration (when negative pressure draws air in) and outward during expiration, which is the opposite of normal chest wall motion-this is termed paradoxical breathing.
  • This paradoxical motion leads to:
    • Impaired ventilation (due to ineffective pressure generation)
    • Increased dead space and hypoventilation
    • Risk of pulmonary contusion, edema, and atelectasis
    • Clinical features like chest pain, respiratory distress, and tachypnea
  • Diagnosis is suspected clinically and confirmed with imaging:
    • Chest X-ray shows rib fractures
    • CT scan with 3D reconstruction is more sensitive and specific
  • Management includes:
    • Pain control (nerve blocks, epidural)
    • Oxygen supplementation
    • Non-invasive or mechanical ventilation in severe cases
    • Surgical rib fixation in select patients

Explanation of other options:

Kussmaul breathing (Option A): Deep, rapid breathing due to metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis); unrelated to trauma or chest wall mechanics.

Apneustic breathing (Option C): Abnormal breathing pattern with prolonged inspiration seen in pons lesions; not associated with rib fractures.

Bronchial breathing (Option D): High-pitched breath sounds heard over areas of lung consolidation (e.g., pneumonia); not related to chest wall trauma.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534090/

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past 5 days. He gives a history of heavy alcohol consumption. Blood investigations reveal amylase and lipase levels elevated five times the upper limit of normal. He received 2 liters of intravenous saline in the last 24 hours. Chest X-ray is shown below: Based on the clinical and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral lung opacities. Acute pancreatitis can lead to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (ARDS) due to systemic inflammation and capillary leakage, seen as bilateral diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray.

  • This patient has acute pancreatitis, likely alcohol-induced, with classical symptoms (epigastric pain radiating to the back) and elevated amylase/lipase.
  • The chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral opacities, which, in the setting of acute pancreatitis, are most consistent with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, specifically acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • Mechanism:
    • Acute pancreatitis leads to systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
    • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6, IL-8) increase capillary permeability in pulmonary vasculature.
    • This leads to protein-rich alveolar edema, not caused by heart failure - hence non-cardiogenic.
    • ARDS is a known complication of pancreatitis.
  • Berlin Definition of ARDS:
    • Timing: Within 1 week of a known insult (e.g., pancreatitis)
    • Chest imaging: Bilateral opacities
    • Origin: Not explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload
    • Oxygenation: PaO2/FiO2 ratio used to classify severity
  • Management:
    • Supportive care with lung-protective ventilation
    • Conservative fluid management
    • Prone positioning, high PEEP in moderate/severe cases
    • Avoid overhydration, which can worsen pulmonary edema

Management according to grade of ARDS

Explanation of other options:

Aspiration pneumonia (Option A): Typically causes localized infiltrates (often in the right lower lobe) with a history of vomiting, altered sensorium, or seizures. It doesn't match the diffuse bilateral opacities seen here.

Miliary tuberculosis (Option C): Presents with tiny, uniform nodules ("millet seed" pattern) and systemic features like fever, weight loss, night sweats. It's a chronic illness, not acute, and unrelated to acute pancreatitis.

Bilateral pulmonary embolism (Option D): Presents with acute dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxia, and possibly clear chest X-ray (may show Westermark sign or Hampton's hump, rarely bilateral infiltrates). PE is not typically associated with pancreatitis or diffuse infiltrates.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7997862/

choices.text: Cardioversion in a hemodynamically unstable patient
Beta blockers are to be given for rate control if the patient is intolerant to calcium channel blockers
IV digoxin for ventricular rate control

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, she has bilateral basal crackles and an irregularly irregular pulse. ECG done is shown below. Which of the following management methods is least useful in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

ECG shows absent P waves with an irregularly irregular ventricular rate, suspecting atrial fibrillation with acute decompensated heart failure. Beta-blockers are not preferred in acute decompensated heart failure due to their negative inotropic effect, which may worsen cardiac output.

  • This patient presents with acute atrial fibrillation (AF) and signs of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF)-dyspnea, basal crackles, and irregularly irregular pulse.
  • Management in this setting prioritizes rate control, rhythm control, and stroke prevention through anticoagulation.
  • In acute settings with hemodynamic instability, synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice to rapidly restore sinus rhythm.
  • In stable patients with ADHF, rate control is preferred initially.
  • However, beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers (like diltiazem/verapamil) should be avoided in the acute decompensated phase due to their negative inotropic effect, which can reduce myocardial contractility and worsen heart failure.
  • Therefore, giving beta blockers when calcium channel blockers are not tolerated is not appropriate in this setting.
  • In contrast, IV digoxin can be used for rate control in AF with heart failure, especially when systolic function is compromised, as it has minimal impact on contractility acutely.
  • Additionally, Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) are essential in AF to reduce the risk of thromboembolic complications, such as stroke.

Explanation of other options:

Cardioversion in a hemodynamically unstable patient (Option A): Appropriate and often life-saving in AF with hemodynamic instability. This is the treatment of choice in acute decompensated heart failure with AF when the patient is unstable.

Direct oral anticoagulants (Option B): Crucial to prevent thromboembolic complications like stroke in patients with AF. DOACs are preferred over warfarin unless contraindicated.

IV digoxin for ventricular rate control (Option D): Useful in controlling ventricular rate in AF when beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers are contraindicated, particularly in patients with heart failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old asymptomatic male undergoes routine medical evaluation for job recruitment. His ECG reveals a PR interval of 0.21 seconds, but no dropped beats or irregular rhythms are noted. He has no history of cardiovascular disease and no symptoms like palpitations or syncope. What is the most appropriate diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

A PR interval >0.20 seconds with no dropped beats is diagnostic of first-degree AV block.

  • First-degree AV block is defined by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) on ECG, representing delayed conduction through the AV node or proximal conduction system.
  • Importantly, every P wave is followed by a QRS complex, indicating that conduction is delayed but not blocked.
  • Etiologies include:
    • Increased vagal tone (in athletes or young individuals)
    • Fibrosis of the conduction system in the elderly
    • Myocardial ischemia, MI
    • Drugs (e.g., beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin)
    • Infectious/inflammatory diseases (e.g., Lyme disease, rheumatic fever, myocarditis)
    • Infiltrative diseases (sarcoidosis, amyloidosis)
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually asymptomatic
    • Rarely, patients with very prolonged PR intervals may experience symptoms due to atrial contraction occurring too early before ventricular filling ("pseudo-pacemaker syndrome")
  • ECG Features:
    • PR interval >0.20 seconds
    • Regular rhythm
    • No dropped QRS complexes
  • Management:
    • Typically no treatment is needed
    • Periodic follow-up with ECG
    • Consider pacing only if associated with symptoms or other conduction disease

ECG's of Heart Blocks

Explanation of other options:

Normal ECG (Option B): The upper limit of a normal PR interval is 0.20 seconds; a PR of 0.21 seconds is prolonged, thus not a normal finding.

2nd-degree block (Option C): Characterized by intermittent dropped QRS complexes:

  • Mobitz I (Wenckebach): Progressive PR lengthening followed by a dropped beat.
  • Mobitz II: Sudden dropped beats without PR prolongation. Neither are seen in this case.

Complete heart block (Option D): There is no AV conduction; the atria and ventricles beat independently, and PR intervals are variable or unrelated. This is not consistent with a constant prolonged PR interval and 1:1 conduction.

Reference:

First-Degree Heart Block - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

1st degree heart block: Causes, symptoms, and treatment

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of death in a patient with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Respiratory failure is the most common terminal event in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis due to progressive loss of functional lung tissue.

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown cause that leads to irreversible decline in lung function.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Repeated alveolar epithelial injury (from smoking, infections, GERD) leads to fibroblast proliferation and excess collagen deposition.
    • This fibrosis distorts lung architecture and progressively impairs gas exchange.
    • The end result is hypoxic respiratory failure, the primary cause of death in most IPF cases.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and exercise intolerance.
    • Fine "Velcro-like" end-inspiratory crackles on auscultation.
    • Digital clubbing is seen in up to 50% of cases.
    • Advanced disease shows resting hypoxemia and right heart strain.
  • Diagnosis:
    • HRCT chest: Peripheral, basal-predominant fibrosis, reticulations, and honeycombing, classic usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern.
    • Lung biopsy (VATS): Confirms UIP, fibroblast foci, temporal heterogeneity, and architectural distortion.
  • Management:
    • Pirfenidone and Nintedanib slow disease progression.
    • Supportive care: Pulmonary rehab, supplemental O2, and vaccination.
    • Lung transplantation offers survival benefits in advanced cases.
  • Complications and Mortality:
    • Most common cause of death: Respiratory failure
    • Other causes: Heart failure, lung carcinoma, infection, ischemic heart disease.
    • IPF is also associated with:
      • Pulmonary hypertension (due to chronic hypoxia)
      • Thromboembolism
      • Lung cancer (especially bronchogenic carcinoma)
  • Prognosis:
    • Median survival: 3-5 years post-diagnosis.
    • Acute exacerbations and infections can accelerate decline.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary hypertension (Option A): While common in advanced IPF, it is usually a complication, not the most frequent direct cause of death.

Pulmonary embolism (Option B): Can occur due to immobility or comorbidities but is a less frequent cause of death compared to respiratory failure.

Lung carcinoma (Option D): Patients with IPF have an increased risk of developing lung cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, but it is not the leading cause of death.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2183601/#

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448162/

choices.text: Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency
Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII
Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood
Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding von Willebrand disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Type 1 von Willebrand disease causes only mild to moderate bleeding symptoms and typically does not present with severe bleeding early in life.

  • Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, resulting from a quantitative or qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF), a glycoprotein critical for platelet adhesion and stabilization of factor VIII.
  • Classification of vWD:
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Mild bleeding (Type 1): Easy bruising, epistaxis, prolonged bleeding after dental procedures, menorrhagia.
    • Moderate bleeding (Type 2): Subtypes show qualitative dysfunction in vWF.
    • Severe bleeding (Type 3): Presents like severe Hemophilia A due to virtual absence of both vWF and Factor VIII.
    • Common symptoms:
      • Mucocutaneous bleeding
      • Post-surgical or dental procedure hemorrhage
      • Prolonged bleeding time despite normal platelet count
  • Treatment:

questions.text: A physician is evaluating a patient for an occupational disease and finds that a coproporphyrin test has been performed. Which of the following conditions is most likely suspected?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Lead poisoning disrupts heme biosynthesis, resulting in elevated urinary coproporphyrin, making it a key diagnostic clue.

  • Lead poisoning, particularly from occupational exposure, interferes with heme synthesis by inhibiting several key enzymes such as δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and ferrochelatase, leading to accumulation of heme precursors including coproporphyrin and δ-ALA (aminolevulinic acid) in the urine.
  • Investigations in Lead Poisoning:
    • Blood Findings:
      • Microcytic hypochromic anemia
      • Basophilic stippling of RBCs
      • Cabot rings
      • ↑ Zinc protoporphyrin (ZnPP)
      • ↑ Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP)
      • ↑ Blood lead levels (>5 µg/dL is significant; >40 µg/dL may show symptoms)
    • Urine Findings:
      • ↑ Urinary ALA (>5 µg/L)
      • ↑ Urinary coproporphyrin (>150 µg/L)
      • ↑ Urinary lead (>0.25 mg/L)
    • Radiological Findings (especially in children):
      • "Lead lines" (dense metaphyseal bands) seen at long bone metaphyses due to inhibited osteoclastic activity.
    • Special Tests:
      • Calcium disodium EDTA mobilization test (especially in children) to assess response to chelation therapy.
  • Pathophysiology of Coproporphyrin Elevation:
    • Lead inhibits the enzymes involved in the conversion of porphyrin precursors to heme, including:
      • δ-ALA dehydratase
      • Ferrochelatase
    • This leads to an accumulation of porphyrin intermediates like coproporphyrin and ALA, which are excreted in urine and used diagnostically.

Explanation of other options:

Berylliosis (Option B): Occupational granulomatous lung disease due to beryllium exposure. Diagnosed via imaging and lung biopsy, not associated with porphyrin abnormalities.

Silicosis (Option C): Caused by inhalation of silica dust leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Diagnosis is based on chest imaging and history of exposure, not urinary porphyrin tests.

Asbestosis (Option D): Chronic interstitial lung disease from asbestos exposure. Diagnosed via imaging (e.g., pleural plaques on X-ray/CT), not via heme biosynthesis markers.

questions.text: What is the confirmatory test for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The given condition is Tuberculoma. NMR spectroscopy detects specific lipid peaks and metabolic profiles that help confirm tuberculoma and differentiate it from neurocysticercosis.

  • NMR spectroscopy (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy) is a non-invasive biochemical imaging technique that analyzes the chemical composition of brain lesions.
  • It is especially helpful when CT or MRI shows ring-enhancing lesions, where the differential diagnosis includes tuberculoma vs. neurocysticercosis.
  • Key Spectroscopic Finding in Tuberculoma:
    • Prominent lipid peak at 1.3 ppm. This is the hallmark finding of caseating tuberculoma.
    • Helps differentiate from neurocysticercosis, which lacks a strong lipid peak and may show other metabolites like lactate.
  • Intracranial Tuberculoma - Diagnostic Imaging:

Explanation of other options:

CBNAAT of CSF (Option A): Useful in diagnosing tuberculous meningitis by detecting MTB DNA, but not confirmatory for parenchymal tuberculoma and does not distinguish it from other ring-enhancing lesions.

PET scan (Option B): Shows increased metabolic activity, but is non-specific and cannot biochemically differentiate tuberculoma vs. neurocysticercosis.

MRI aerial scan (Option D): Not a recognized term in clinical radiology. Standard MRI provides anatomical detail, but lacks metabolic resolution offered by spectroscopy.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4845155/

questions.text:
A 30-year-old patient presents with weakness. Laboratory values are as follows:
Blood pH: 7.3
Na+: 134 mEq/L
K+: 2.8 mEq/L
Cl-: 113 mEq/L
HCO3-: 12 mEq/L
BUN: 3 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
Urinary pH: 9.4
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia, high urinary pH, and low serum bicarbonate is characteristic of Type I (distal) renal tubular acidosis.

  • Type I Renal Tubular Acidosis (Distal RTA) is caused by a defect in hydrogen ion secretion in the distal nephron, resulting in an inability to acidify urine despite systemic acidosis.
  • Key Findings in This Case:
    • Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.3 and HCO3- = 12 mEq/L)
    • Hypokalemia (K+ = 2.8 mEq/L)
    • Hyperchloremia (Cl- = 113 mEq/L)
    • Urinary pH = 9.4 (inappropriately high → confirms defective distal acidification)
    • Normal anion gap: AG = Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-) = 134 - (113 + 12) = 9 mEq/L
  • These features are diagnostic of Type I RTA, especially the inappropriately alkaline urine in the presence of systemic acidosis.
  • Additional Clues Supporting Type I RTA:
    • Often associated with autoimmune diseases, hypergammaglobulinemia, or drugs like amphotericin B
  • Long-term complication: nephrocalcinosis and renal stones
  • Treatment: Potassium citrate or oral bicarbonate supplementation

Explanation of other options:

Type II Renal Tubular Acidosis (Option B): Proximal RTA presents with low urinary pH (<5.3) after initial bicarbonate loss and typically has less severe hypokalemia. Urinary pH >9.0 is inconsistent with Type II RTA.

Type IV Renal Tubular Acidosis (Option C): Caused by hypoaldosteronism, it presents with hyperkalemia and mild acidosis. In this case, potassium is low, not high.

High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (Option D): Calculated AG = 9 → Normal, so this rules out HAGMA (e.g., due to lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis, renal failure, toxins).

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Characteristics-of-the-types-of-renal-tubular-acidosis_tbl5_328347660

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Diagnostic-criteria-for-renal-tubular-acidosis_tbl4_267744743

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519044/#

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers are given to all patients
Lung transplant is the best treatment if identified early
Lifestyle modification is the only possible approach

questions.text: An elderly female with a known history of scleroderma presents with shortness of breath. On clinical evaluation, her right ventricular systolic pressure is found to be 70-80 mmHg, and right heart catheterization reveals a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 35 mmHg. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Endothelin receptor antagonists are effective in improving symptoms and slowing disease progression in pulmonary hypertension, particularly in connective tissue disease-associated PH like in scleroderma.

  • This patient with scleroderma, dyspnea, elevated right ventricular pressure, and elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP = 35 mmHg) is likely suffering from pulmonary hypertension (PH)-specifically group 1 (pulmonary arterial hypertension) or group 2 PH (due to left heart disease) depending on underlying pathology.
  • Pulmonary Hypertension (PH):
    • Defined as mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20 mmHg (updated threshold).
    • In scleroderma, pulmonary hypertension may result from:
      • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) due to vascular remodeling (Group 1)
      • Interstitial lung disease with PH (Group 3)
      • Left heart involvement (diastolic dysfunction) leading to increased PCWP (Group 2)
    • Clinical Clues from the Question:
      • Elevated RV pressure (70-80 mmHg): Sign of significant pulmonary arterial pressure load.
      • PCWP = 35 mmHg (Normal = 6-12): Suggests post-capillary PH (Group 2) possibly from diastolic dysfunction or pulmonary venous hypertension in scleroderma.
    • Symptoms: Dyspnea, fatigue, and signs of right heart failure.
    • Therapeutic Approach:
      • Endothelin Receptor Antagonists (ERAs) (e.g., Bosentan, Ambrisentan) are approved for symptom relief and improved exercise tolerance in PAH, including scleroderma-associated PAH.
      • These block endothelin-1-mediated vasoconstriction and vascular remodeling.
      • Also used in combination therapy with PDE-5 inhibitors or prostanoids in advanced cases.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium channel blockers are given to all patients (Option A): CCBs are indicated only in patients with a positive vasoreactivity test (seen in ~10% of idiopathic PAH). They are not beneficial and may be harmful in connective tissue-associated PAH like in scleroderma.

Lung transplant is the best treatment if identified early (Option B): Transplant is reserved for advanced, treatment-refractory cases, not early-stage disease. Pharmacological therapy is preferred initially.

Lifestyle modification is the only possible approach (Option D): Lifestyle changes (e.g., sodium restriction, exercise, oxygen therapy) are supportive but not curative. Targeted pharmacologic therapies are essential for symptom control and survival benefit.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482463/

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with fever, chills, and a productive cough. His vital signs reveal a BP of 150/88 mmHg, pulse rate of 110 bpm, respiratory rate of 18/min, and SpO2 of 88% on room air. A chest X-ray was performed and is shown below.
What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The combination of fever, cough with sputum, hypoxia, and lobar consolidation on chest X-ray is most consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

  • This clinical scenario strongly indicates community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which presents acutely with systemic and respiratory symptoms and radiographic signs of consolidation.
  • Etiology:
    • Typical pathogens: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus
    • Atypical pathogens: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Legionella, influenza virus
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms: Fever, chills, productive cough, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain
    • Signs: Increased respiratory rate, hypoxia, dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, bronchial breath sounds, crepitations
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Chest X-ray in CAP shows:
      • New lobar infiltrates/consolidation
      • May involve cavitation or multilobar disease in severe cases
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical + Radiographic correlation is key
  • Supportive tests: CBC, CRP, procalcitonin, blood cultures, sputum Gram stain and culture, urine antigen for Legionella and S. pneumoniae
  • Severity Assessment - CURB-65 Criteria:
    • Criteria - Points
    • Confusion - 1
    • Urea >7 mmol/L - 1
    • Respiratory rate >30 - 1
    • BP <90 systolic or <60 diastolic - 1
    • Age ≥ 65 years. - 1
      • Score 0: Treat outpatient
      • Score 1-2: Hospital admission
      • Score ≥3: ICU care
  • Treatment:
    • Score Recommended Regimen
    • 0 Amoxicillin + macrolide/doxycycline, or monotherapy with either
    • 1-2 β-lactam + macrolide, or respiratory fluoroquinolone
    • ≥3 β-lactam + macrolide or β-lactam + fluoroquinolone (IV)

Explanation of other options:

Tubercular pleural effusion (Option A): Usually presents with pleuritic chest pain, dullness, and decreased breath sounds. Imaging shows blunted costophrenic angle or meniscus sign, not lobar consolidation.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C): Chronic occupational disease with small upper lobe opacities. No acute presentation with fever or lobar consolidation.

Silicosis (Option D): Due to silica exposure, it shows multiple small upper lobe nodules with possible eggshell calcification of lymph nodes. No acute systemic symptoms or lobar involvement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue and hemoptysis. His hemoglobin has dropped from 12 g/dL to 8 g/dL in one week. Bronchoalveolar lavage reveals a reddish fluid, and his serum creatinine is elevated at 1.7 mg/dL. He tests ANCA-positive, and a renal biopsy shows pauci-immune glomerulonephritis without granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Microscopic polyangiitis presents with ANCA-positive pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and pulmonary-renal syndrome, without granulomas.

  • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a pauci-immune small vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.
  • The hallmark features include:
    • Hemoptysis (due to alveolar hemorrhage)
    • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (causing a drop in hemoglobin, elevated creatinine)
    • ANCA positivity - typically p-ANCA (anti-MPO antibodies)
    • Pauci-immune pattern on renal biopsy (minimal immune complex deposition)
    • Absence of granulomatous inflammation (unlike GPA or Churg-Strauss)
  • This clinical presentation of pulmonary-renal syndrome, especially with no granulomas, strongly favors MPA.

Microvascular Vasculitis:

Explanation of other options:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option C): SLE causes immune complex-mediated (not pauci-immune) nephritis and is typically ANA positive. It does not usually present with ANCA-positive vasculitis or isolated pulmonary-renal syndrome.

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (Option D): HSP is an IgA-mediated vasculitis seen mainly in children, with purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement. Pulmonary hemorrhage and ANCA positivity are uncommon.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a known history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted with acute exacerbation. He is placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress. During ventilation, his oxygen saturation begins to fall consistently. On auscultation, vesicular breath sounds are heard on the right side, and chest X-ray was done and shown below. What is the most likely finding on auscultation of the left side of the chest?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Chest X-ray reveals a hyperlucent left hemithorax with absent vascular markings and mediastinal shift to the right.
