In left-sided pneumothorax, air in the pleural space prevents transmission of breath sounds, resulting in absent breath sounds on auscultation.

  • In a patient with COPD on mechanical ventilation, the sudden drop in oxygen saturation, along with hyperlucency on chest X-ray and absent vascular markings, strongly suggests the development of a pneumothorax, specifically on the left side in this case.
  • Mechanical ventilation, especially with positive pressure, increases the risk of barotrauma, which may cause rupture of already fragile lung tissue (common in emphysematous lungs of COPD patients), leading to a secondary spontaneous or tension pneumothorax.

Classic signs of pneumothorax:

  • Inspection: Asymmetric chest movement, respiratory distress
  • Palpation: Reduced/absent tactile fremitus on affected side
  • Percussion: Hyperresonant note on the side of pneumothorax
  • Auscultation: Absent or markedly reduced breath sounds over the affected side
  • Other signs: Tracheal/mediastinal shift (if tension pneumothorax), hypoxemia, hypotension

Explanation of other options:

Bronchial breath sounds (Option B): Bronchial breath sounds are heard over areas of lung consolidation (e.g., pneumonia), not in pneumothorax, where the lung is collapsed and displaced by air in the pleural space.

Increased vesicular breath sounds (Option C): Vesicular breath sounds are normal and may be slightly increased over hyperinflated but aerated lungs; in pneumothorax, breath sounds are typically absent, not increased.

Increased vocal fremitus (Option D): Fremitus is increased in consolidated lung, but decreased or absent in pneumothorax due to the insulating effect of free air in the pleural cavity.

Reference:

https://pubs.rsna.org/doi/abs/10.1148/radiol.2282020524?journalCode=radiology

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pneumothorax

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17419871/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11464087/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5849448/

questions.text:
Match the following ECG waves with the conditions:
a) Atrial flutter
b) Atrial fibrillation
c) Ventricular tachycardia
d) Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
1. 2. 3. 4.
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The correctly matched option is A) a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3

Atrial Flutter:

In atrial flutter, the standard PR interval is absent due to the presence of continuous, rapid flutter waves instead of discrete P waves. These flutter waves occur in a regular pattern at a rate of 250-350 beats per minute, producing the classic "sawtooth" appearance on ECG. Since the AV node conducts only a fraction of these impulses (commonly 2:1 or 4:1), the ventricular rhythm remains organized, but without a definable PR interval.

Atrial Fibrillation (AF):

The ECG in AF displays an irregularly irregular rhythm with normal QRS complexes. P waves are absent, and the baseline shows erratic, low-amplitude fibrillatory waves. The ventricular rate is typically rapid at onset (120-160 beats/min), but may become slower in chronic cases due to AV nodal fatigue or medication effects.

Ventricular Tachycardia (VT):

In monomorphic VT, the ECG shows wide QRS complexes (>120 ms) with a regular rhythm and uniform morphology across leads. The QRS axis varies based on the site of origin and may resemble either left or right bundle branch block patterns. In polymorphic VT, such as Torsades de Pointes, the QRS morphology changes continuously and is often linked to a prolonged QT interval.

Paroxysmal Ventricular Tachycardia:

This arrhythmia presents on ECG as a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia with QRS duration less than 120 ms and shortened R-R intervals. The heart rate typically ranges between 150-250 beats per minute. P waves are frequently absent or hidden within the T waves.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with complaints of lethargy and persistent tiredness. On physical examination, he has noticeable perioral hyperpigmentation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and heart rate is 110 beats/minute. Laboratory investigations reveal serum sodium of 125 mEq/L and serum potassium of 5.5 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Hydrocortisone with fludrocortisone is the treatment of choice in Addison's disease, as it replaces both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.

  • The constellation of symptoms; lethargy, postural hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and biochemical findings of hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are characteristic of Addison's disease, i.e., primary adrenal insufficiency.
  • This condition results from adrenal cortex failure, leading to deficiencies in cortisol, aldosterone, and adrenal androgens.
  • The low cortisol causes fatigue, hypoglycemia, and hypotension, while aldosterone deficiency leads to hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and volume depletion.
  • ACTH levels are elevated due to loss of feedback inhibition, resulting in skin and mucosal hyperpigmentation.
  • Etiology:
    • Most common worldwide: Autoimmune adrenalitis
    • Most common in India: Tuberculosis
    • Other causes: HIV/AIDS, metastatic cancer, bilateral adrenalectomy, histoplasmosis
  • Investigations:
    • Random plasma cortisol: <100 nmol/L strongly suggests adrenal insufficiency
    • Short ACTH stimulation test: Cortisol <500 nmol/L post-ACTH confirms the diagnosis
    • Plasma renin ↑, aldosterone ↓: Indicates mineralocorticoid deficiency
    • Adrenal autoantibodies: In autoimmune cases
    • CT/MRI: Indicated if autoimmune antibodies are negative
  • Treatment:
    • Hydrocortisone: First-line glucocorticoid replacement
    • Fludrocortisone: Essential mineralocorticoid for sodium and volume regulation
    • Supportive therapy: Salt supplementation, patient education on stress-dose steroids
    • In acute adrenal crisis: IV hydrocortisone + normal saline + dextrose infusion

Explanation of other options:

ACTH (Option A): ACTH is used diagnostically in the short synacthen test, but not therapeutically. It has no benefit in Addison's disease because the adrenal glands cannot respond due to intrinsic damage.

Dexamethasone (Option C): Although effective as a glucocorticoid, dexamethasone lacks mineralocorticoid activity, making it inadequate as monotherapy for Addison's, where both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement are necessary.

Saline infusion (Option D): While useful in managing acute hypotension, it only provides temporary hemodynamic support. It does not correct the hormonal deficits, and without steroid replacement, symptoms will recur or worsen.

choices.text: Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluoroquinolones
Mutation only to INH A and kat G gene

questions.text: For MDR-RR TB, what is the indication of short course bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Short-course bedaquiline-containing regimens are indicated for MDR/RR-TB patients who are rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive.

  • Multidrug-resistant / Rifampicin-resistant tuberculosis (MDR/RR-TB) is defined by resistance to rifampicin, with or without resistance to other first-line drugs.
  • The short-course bedaquiline-containing regimen (typically the 6-month BPaLM regimen) is indicated when the strain is resistant to rifampicin but remains sensitive to fluoroquinolones.
  • BPaLM Regimen Components:
    • Bedaquiline
    • Pretomanid
    • Linezolid (600 mg)
    • Moxifloxacin
  • WHO Endorsed Regimen Use:
    • Indicated when:
      • Confirmed Rifampicin resistance (MDR/RR-TB)
      • Confirmed Fluoroquinolone susceptibility
      • Age ≥14 years
      • Non-CNS involvement
      • No prior exposure to any BPaLM drugs >1 month unless drug resistance to them is ruled out
    • Not recommended in:
      • TB meningitis or CNS TB
      • Pregnancy and lactation
      • Age <14 years
      • Known exposure to BPaLM drugs for over 30 days without confirmed susceptibility

Explanation of other options:

Mutation only to INH A and katG gene (Option B): Indicates isoniazid resistance, but rifampicin resistance is required to define MDR/RR-TB. Without rifampicin resistance, the patient does not qualify for bedaquiline-based MDR therapy.

Rifampicin sensitive (Option C): First-line anti-TB drugs are used for rifampicin-sensitive TB. Short-course bedaquiline regimens are specifically for rifampicin-resistant cases.

Extrapulmonary TB like tubercular meningitis (Option D): Bedaquiline has poor CNS penetration, and tubercular meningitis is a contraindication for short-course regimens due to limited efficacy.

Reference:

https://pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2070942#

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11257606/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4561400/

https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/365333/9789240065116-eng.pdf?sequence=1

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971223000899

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration due to cobalamin deficiency

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with fatigue, tingling sensation in the arms, weight loss, and a history of polyuria. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, and the findings are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The presence of plasmacytosis in the bone marrow, along with symptoms like polyuria (from hypercalcemia), neuropathy, fatigue, and weight loss, strongly indicates multiple myeloma.

Bone marrow biopsy findings: Numerous plasma cells with eccentric nuclei, perinuclear clearing (hof), and basophilic cytoplasm consistent with plasmacytosis.

  • Multiple myeloma (MM) is a plasma cell malignancy characterized by monoclonal proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow, leading to overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulin or light chains (M protein).
  • Key Clinical Clues in This Case:
    • Fatigue and weight loss → Constitutional symptoms
    • Tingling in arms → Neuropathy (common due to paraproteinemia or amyloidosis)
    • Polyuria → Due to hypercalcemia (part of CRAB criteria)
    • Bone marrow biopsy → Shows >10% abnormal plasma cells (as seen in the image)
  • Diagnostic Features of MM:
    • Bone marrow plasmacytosis >10% (as seen on histology)
    • CRAB Criteria:
      • C: Hypercalcemia
      • R: Renal dysfunction
      • A: Anemia
      • B: Bone lesions (lytic lesions on imaging)
    • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP): M-spike
    • Urine: Bence Jones protein
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
    • Flow cytometry: CD138+ plasma cells
    • FISH: High-risk cytogenetics (e.g., 17p deletion)
    • Imaging:
      • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
      • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
      • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease

Explanation of other options:

Subacute combined degeneration due to cobalamin deficiency (Option A): Presents with neurological symptoms like paresthesia and loss of proprioception but does not cause hypercalcemia or plasma cell proliferation in bone marrow.

Subacute degeneration due to diabetes (Option C): Refers to diabetic neuropathy, which causes tingling and numbness but no marrow abnormalities or CRAB features.

Megaloblastic anemia (Option D): Results from B12 or folate deficiency, causes macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms, but not hypercalcemia or increased plasma cells on biopsy.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6650180/

https://journals.lww.com/jasn/fulltext/2022/11001/hyperuricemia_and_kidney_function_in_patients.2257.aspx

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4973001/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0009912006003213#

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539757/#

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8627691/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/biochemistry-genetics-and-molecular-biology/immunofixation#:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18648809/

choices.text: Ankle clonus in the right foot
Proprioception lost in the left leg
Pain and temperature were lost in the right leg

questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffered a road traffic accident (RTA). A few days later, he presents with exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and increased right knee jerk. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

These findings are consistent with an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.

Clonus is a classic sign of upper motor neuron lesions, typically seen along with hyperreflexia and extensor plantar response.

  • The signs described-exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk) and extensor plantar response (Babinski sign)-are characteristic of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion affecting the right side.
  • UMN lesions commonly occur in:
    • Spinal cord trauma
    • Stroke
    • Multiple sclerosis
    • Cerebral palsy
  • One of the hallmark features of UMN lesions is clonus-involuntary rhythmic contractions typically seen at the ankle or patella when the muscle is stretched.
  • Ankle clonus, therefore, is a logical and expected associated finding in this patient with right-sided UMN signs.

Comparison of UMN Vs LMN

Explanation of other options:

Proprioception lost in the left leg (Option B): Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column, which ascends ipsilaterally in the spinal cord and decussates in the medulla. A right-sided spinal cord lesion would impair right-sided proprioception, not left-sided.

Pain and temperature lost in the right leg (Option C): Pain and temperature sensations travel in the spinothalamic tract, which crosses at the level of entry into the spinal cord. A right-sided lesion would affect left-sided pain and temperature sensation, not right.

Fasciculations in the right foot (Option D): Fasciculations are a sign of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion, not UMN. LMN signs include flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and reduced reflexes; none of which match this case.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537305/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/lower-motor-neuron-lesion

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541082/#

questions.text: A patient who was involved in a road traffic accident (RTA) underwent ileal resection. He now presents with fatigue. Which of the following is NOT expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Microcytic hypochromic anemia is typically seen in iron deficiency, not in vitamin B12 deficiency, which occurs after ileal resection and causes macrocytic anemia.

  • The terminal ileum is essential for vitamin B12 absorption, facilitated by intrinsic factor.
  • Ileal resection impairs this process, leading to vitamin B12 deficiency, which results in:
    • Macrocytic anemia
    • Neurological symptoms due to subacute combined degeneration (SACD)
    • Proprioceptive loss and Romberg's sign
    • Cytoplasmic-nuclear dys-synchrony on bone marrow biopsy
  • Key Features of Vitamin B12 Deficiency (Post-Ileal Resection):
    • Anemia Type: Macrocytic, not microcytic
    • Neurologic: Peripheral neuropathy, sensory ataxia, SACD
    • Histology: Hypersegmented neutrophils, megaloblastic changes
    • Bone Marrow: Cytoplasmic maturation continues, but nuclear maturation is delayed → cyto-nuclear dys-synchrony (Option A ruled out)
    • Romberg's sign: Positive due to dorsal column involvement (Option C ruled out)
    • Subacute Combined Degeneration: Posterior and lateral column demyelination (Option D ruled out)

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441923/

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg negative
Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive

questions.text: A young man had a history of jaundice and raised HBsAg levels a year back. On follow-up now, he has normal levels of liver enzymes. His current profile is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis for his current condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Persistent HBsAg positivity >6 months, HBeAg positivity, and anti-HBc IgG indicate chronic active Hepatitis B with ongoing viral replication.

  • The key diagnostic criteria for chronic Hepatitis B infection are:
    • Persistence of HBsAg for >6 months
    • Presence of anti-HBc IgG
    • Absence of anti-HBs
  • In this case, the patient continues to have HBsAg positivity after 1 year, indicating chronic infection.
  • The presence of HBeAg implies active viral replication and high infectivity.
  • Since anti-HBc IgG is positive and IgM is negative, the acute phase is over, confirming the chronic stage.
  • There are two main types of chronic Hepatitis B:
    • HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis B: High infectivity, active replication
    • HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B (precore mutant): Lower replication, often inactive phase or fluctuating activity
  • The current serology fits the HBeAg-positive type, with active replication and potential for liver damage even if enzymes are temporarily normal.

Acute HBV infection with recovery

Chronic HBV infection

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/354997816_Hepatitis_B_Vaccines

questions.text: A 40-year-old female, known case of myasthenia gravis on mycophenolate mofetil and pyridostigmine, now presents with breathing difficulties. Her serum calcium is found to be 13.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely cause of her hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Primary hyperparathyroidism, most commonly due to a parathyroid adenoma, is the most likely cause of persistent, significant hypercalcemia in this patient.

  • Hypercalcemia in this patient is unlikely to be drug-induced or paraneoplastic given her background and medication.
  • The most consistent and common cause of chronic hypercalcemia, especially with levels >13 mg/dL, is primary hyperparathyroidism, which is most frequently caused by a parathyroid adenoma.
  • Myasthenia gravis and her treatment do not explain hypercalcemia. The finding is likely incidental and points toward coexisting primary hyperparathyroidism.

Primary Hyperparathyroidism

  • Cause: Solitary adenoma (∼80% cases)
  • Pathophysiology: Excess PTH secretion → ↑ bone resorption, ↑ renal calcium reabsorption, ↓ phosphate reabsorption
  • Symptoms mnemonic: "Stones, Bones, Groans, Psychiatric Moans"
    • Stones: Nephrolithiasis
    • Bones: Osteitis fibrosa cystica, bone pain
    • Groans: Constipation, abdominal pain
    • Psychiatric Moans: Depression, confusion
  • Serum Findings: ↑ Ca2+, ↓ PO43-, ↑ PTH, normal or high ALP

Explanation of other options:

Small cell carcinoma of lung (Option A): This tumor is associated with SIADH and ectopic ACTH, not hypercalcemia.

Drug-induced hypercalcemia (Option B): Neither mycophenolate mofetil nor pyridostigmine are associated with hypercalcemia.

Adenocarcinoma lung (Option D): This histological type rarely causes hypercalcemia. If any lung cancer does, it's squamous cell carcinoma via PTHrP secretion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with hyperthermia, autonomic instability, confusion, hyperreflexia, muscle rigidity, and dilated pupils. He has been taking sertraline and was recently prescribed amitriptyline and sumatriptan for depression and migraines, respectively. Which medication is most likely to be effective in treating his current condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist, is the treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome, which is suggested by this patient's clinical features and drug history.

  • This patient presents with classic signs of serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity in the CNS.
  • Key features include:
    • Mental status changes: confusion, agitation
    • Neuromuscular hyperactivity: hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity
    • Autonomic instability: tachycardia, diaphoresis, hyperthermia
    • Mydriasis (dilated pupils)
  • Precipitating factors in this case:
    • Sertraline (SSRI): increases serotonin by inhibiting reuptake
    • Amitriptyline (TCA): inhibits serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake
    • Sumatriptan: 5-HT1B/1D agonist, may exacerbate serotonergic effects when combined with SSRIs or TCAs
  • Management of Serotonin Syndrome:
    • Discontinue all serotonergic agents
    • Supportive care: IV fluids, benzodiazepines for agitation
    • Cyproheptadine: a 5-HT2A receptor antagonist, is used orally in moderate to severe cases and helps reverse the serotonergic toxicity

Explanation of other options:

Propranolol (Option B): Non-selective beta-blocker. Can worsen hypotension or mask signs of autonomic instability. Not used in serotonin syndrome.

Diphenhydramine (Option C): An H1-antihistamine; not effective against serotonergic activity. May worsen confusion or sedation.

Nitroprusside (Option D): A vasodilator used for hypertensive emergencies; not indicated here. The hypertension in serotonin syndrome is best managed with supportive care and cyproheptadine if needed.
